title: In Chapter 7 means test. I have a sole proprietor business. Am making P&Ls to determine income. Medical Insurance an expense?
question: The question is:
answers:
Since your business is a sole proprietorship "the business" is really you. There is no separate entity. Therefore it is you - not some separate entity - that is paying the medical insurance premium. And it is deductible on line 34 of the means test.

If you were to consider the payment of your medical insurance premium to be an expense of your business then the trustee might contend that the payment of a personal expense by your business should be income to you.

I agree with my colleague from New York. If you pay medical insurance through your company, it should be deemed a business expense and a deduction from income. I also agree that you should consult with your attorney or, if you do not have an attorney, an attorney in your area who will know what your local trustees will and will not accept.

Good luck!

Whether or not it is a "business expense" or not is something your accountant would need to determine (and, if necessary, testify on), but either way there is a separate column for health insurance expenses on the means test form, so if you are still above the median income based on your gross income, you can subtract the medical insurance later.

I disagree aand you should talk to your attorney as to the practice of the local United States Trustee. Medical payments for insurance that are mde from the business re an allowed business epene that will reuce your income and profit. In fact you are not allowed to include the costs of the medical expense in the relevant portion of he means test if it is paid by the company. it is better to cliam a zero expense in the means test and have the business expnse the medicalpayments IF the business has historically made those payments directly as an employee benefit.

You cannot double dip...what I mean is the medical expenses cannot be paid by the business (hence reducing income) and then also taken as an expense item in the means test.
